claim: Toads are technically a type of frog.

supporting.text: Toads and frogs both belong to the order Anura, which means they share the same taxonomic classification as amphibians without tails.

attacks.text: Toads and frogs both belong to the order Anura, which means they share the same taxonomic classification as amphibians without tails.

While toads and frogs are both in the order Anura, toads are classified under the family Bufonidae, which distinguishes them from true frogs (family Ranidae) based on morphological and ecological differences.
Taxonomic families are subdivisions of orders, so belonging to different families does not negate their shared classification under Anura, which supports the claim that toads are a type of frog.

Common usage and biological definitions often distinguish toads from frogs due to traits like dry, warty skin and terrestrial habits, making the claim technically misleading despite taxonomic overlap.
Biological taxonomy prioritizes evolutionary relationships over colloquial distinctions, so the shared order Anura is a stronger indicator of classification than vernacular differences.
